details.title: The NBUT class of life distributions

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat. & Actuarial Sci., Univ. of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, USA

p: Ibrahim A. Ahmad is Professor of Statistics, Head of the Department of Statistics and Actuarial Science. He received the M.Sc. degree (1970) in Statistics, and the Ph.D. degree (1975) in Statistics & OR from Florida State University. He has published over 120 papers on reliability & life testing, applied probability, actuarial science, nonparametrics, and econometrics in journals such as Journal of Applied Probability, Probability in Engineering and Informational Sciences, Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference, Statistics and Probability Letters, Biometrika, Annals of Economics and Finance, Communication in Statistics, Statistical Papers, The American Statistician, among others. He is an elected member, and fellow of American Association for the Advancement of Science, ASA, ISI, IMS, SSC. He is listed in Who is Who in the World, in the USA, 1984 and Who is Who in Science, 1997.

authors.name: I.A. Ahmad

p: Mohamed Kayid obtained the B.Sc. degree (Mathematics, 1991) from Al Menia Uni-versity, the M.Sc. degree (Statistics, 1999) from Al Azhar University, and the Ph.D. degree (Statistics, 2003) from South Valley University. His research interests are in reliability theory & preventive maintenance, stochastic orders, and their applications; and he has published in a variety of International Journals on these issues. In addition to this, his current research is in nonparametric statistics, and life testing. He is an elected Reviewer for American Mathematical Society, and he is a director for Consulting Center in Suez Canal University.

Xiaohu Li is Professor of Statistics; and obtained the B.Sc. degree (Applied Mathematics, 1990), the M.Sc. degree (Statistics, 1995), and the Ph.D. degree (Statistics, 2000) from Lanzhou University. His research interests are in Applied Probability & Statistics Theory of Reliability & Life-Testing. He has published over 20 papers on reliability & applied probability in journals such as J. Applied Probability, Probability in Engineering and Informational Sciences, Statistics & Probability Letters, and Statistical Papers.

details.abstract: A new class of life distributions, namely new better than used in the total time on test transform ordering (NBUT), is introduced. The relationship of this class to other classes of life distributions, and closure properties under some reliability operations, are discussed. We provide a simple argument based on stochastic orders that the family of the NBUT distribution class is closed under the formation of series systems in case of independent identically distributed components. Behavior of this class is developed in terms of the monotonicity of the residual life of k-out-of-n systems given the time at which the (n-k)-th failure has occurred. Finally, we discuss testing exponentially against the NBUT aging property.

references.title: Reversed preservation of stochastic orders for random minima and maxima with applications

context.text: Applications, properties, and interpretations of the \$TTT\$-transform order in the statistical theory of reliability, and in economics can be found in Kochar et al. [15], Li & Zuo [20], and Ahmad & Kayid [5].

Some authors have made efforts to investigate preservation properties of some stochastic orders under random minima & maxima, while others have centered their attention on investigating the behavior of aging properties in coherent structure, parallel (series) systems, convolution, mixture, and renewal process (Bartoszewicz [9], Marshall & Proschan [24], Li & Zuo [20], Ahmad & Kayid [5]).

references.text: I. A. Ahmad, M. Kayid, "Reversed preservation of stochastic orders for random minima and maxima with applications", Statist. Pap., 2005.

references.title: Statistical Theory of Reliability and Life Testing

context.text: Hence, a lot of results related to these two classes have been obtained in the literature (Bryson & Siddiqui [8], Barlow & Proschan [6], Deshpand et al. [10], Li & Kochar [17], Franco et al. [11], Loh [22] and Hu & Xie. [14]).
Useful properties of aging classes of life distributions are the closure with respect to typical reliability operations (see, e.g., Barlow, and Proschan, [6]).

On the other hand, it is a well known fact that some aging notions are preserved under the formation of a parallel or series system (see Barlow & Proschan [6], Abouammoh & El-Neweihi [1], Hendi et al. [13], Li & Kochar [17], and Pellerey & Petakos [25]).

Finally, because mixtures of some exponential life distributions often belong to the decreasing failure rate (DFR) class (Barlow & Proschan, [6]), we conclude that the \$NBUT\$ class is not closed under mixtures.

references.text: R. E. Barlow, F. Proschan, Statistical Theory of Reliability and Life Testing, 1981.

references.title: Some criteria for aging

context.text: By aging, we mean the phenomenon whereby an older system has a shorter remaining lifetime, in some statistical sense, than a younger one (Bryson & Siddiqui, [8]).

Hence, a lot of results related to these two classes have been obtained in the literature (Bryson & Siddiqui [8], Barlow & Proschan [6], Deshpand et al. [10], Li & Kochar [17], Franco et al. [11], Loh [22] and Hu & Xie. [14]).

references.title: Testing whether new is better than used

context.text: The \$NBU\$ positive aging has been discussed & tested early on through the work of Hollander & Proschan [12], and was followed by many authors.
It is possible to propose testing the \$NBUT\$ class along the lines of the \$NBU\$ test proposed by Hollander & Proschan [12].
Note also that the \$NBU\$ test of Hollander & Proschan [12] has efficacy values of the above three alternatives equal to 1.1619, 0.5095, and 0.2582, respectively.

references.text: M. Hollander, F. Proschan, "Testing whether new is better than used", Ann. Math. Statist., vol. 43, pp. 1136-1146, 1972.

links.abstract: It is well-known that the increasing-failure-rate-average (IFRA), new-better-than-used (NBU), and new-better-than-used-in-expectation (NBUE) classes of life distributions are successive generalizations of the class of increasing-failure-rate (IFR) distributions. Further, each of the IFR, IFRA and NBU classes can be characterized in terms of the exponential distribution and certain partial orderings on the family of all distributions. It is not known, however, if the same holds for the NBUE class...

references.text: W. Y. Loh, " A new generalization of the class of \$NBU\$ distribution ", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 33, pp. 419-422, 1984.

links.abstract: The paper by M.I. Hendi et al. (see J. Appl. Probability, vol.30, p.975-8) proves that the family of new better than used in convex order (NBUC) distributions is closed under the formation of parallel systems with i.i.d components. This paper proves, through a simple argument based on stochastic orders, that this property also holds for s-independent but not identically distributed components. The proof presented here, with minor modifications, also provides both the proof of the closure under f...

references.text: F. Pellerey, K. Petakos, "On closure property of the NBUC class under formation of parallel systems", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 51, pp. 452-454, 2002.
